Row.Text: Ancient era anti-cavalry unit. Melee conscription unit. Reduces city's [ICON_Citizen] Population by 1 when completed.

Provides 1 Tourism after advancing to the Conservation Civic. Provides +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture to each Rainforest tile in this city.
Provides +3 [ICON_SCIENCE] Science to each Rainforest tile in this city.
Provides +5 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to each Rainforest tile in this city.
Provides +2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production to each Camp improvement in this city.
Provides +1 [ICON_FOOD] Food to each Pasture improvement in this city.
Heroic Epic
+2 cog, culture, general, writing slots/points

CivV Civilepdia: From ancient times, a heroic epic is a poem that defines a people or an era, and is usually centered upon the heroic actions of one or more people. The Greek Odyssey is such a work, as are the Mesopotamian Epic of Gilgamesh and the Anglo-Saxon Beowulf.
National Library
The national library is either an OP early game building or an ok mid-game building for science

CivV Civilepdia: From ancient times, a heroic epic is a poem that defines a people or an era, and is usually centered upon the heroic actions of one or more people. The Greek Odyssey is such a work, as are the Mesopotamian Epic of Gilgamesh and the Anglo-Saxon Beowulf.
Circus Maximus
Placeholder in case I need to describe buildings special abilities or unique traits

CivV Civilepdia: A massive stadium located in the heart of Rome, the Circus Maximus was the first, and largest, chariot racing venue in ancient Rome. At the time of its usage, it could hold over a quarter of a million people, over 25% of the city's population. Measuring over 500 meters (2000 ft) in length, twelve full-sized chariots could easily race side by side. Originally used by the Etruscan kings to host their entertainments and festivals, the first Roman Games were held at the racetrack by the fifth Roman King, Tarquinius Priscus. The site was later expanded by Julius Caesar in 50 BC to its current size.
Public Bathhouse
Placeholder in case I need to describe buildings special abilities or unique traits

CivV Civilepdia: A massive stadium located in the heart of Rome, the Circus Maximus was the first, and largest, chariot racing venue in ancient Rome. At the time of its usage, it could hold over a quarter of a million people, over 25% of the city's population. Measuring over 500 meters (2000 ft) in length, twelve full-sized chariots could easily race side by side. Originally used by the Etruscan kings to host their entertainments and festivals, the first Roman Games were held at the racetrack by the fifth Roman King, Tarquinius Priscus. The site was later expanded by Julius Caesar in 50 BC to its current size.
Ironworks
Only 2 Ironworks can be built in each empire. Requires city to have an Armory and an Industrial Zone that's built next to an Iron resource

An Ironworks is where iron is smelted at an industrial scale using a blast furnace. Ironworks succeeded bloomeries when blast furnaces replaced former methods. An integrated ironworks in the 19th century usually included one or more blast furnaces and a number of puddling furnaces or a foundry with or without other kinds of ironworks. The earliest cast iron in China dates to the 8th century BC and pre-dates the earliest European evidence by about two millennia.

After the invention of the Bessemer process, converters became widespread, and the appellation steelworks replaced ironworks. The processes carried at ironworks Steelers are usually described as ferrous metallurgy, but the term siderurgy is also occasionally used. This is derived from the Greek words sideros - iron and ergon or ergos - work. This is an unusual term in English, and it is best regarded as an anglicisation of a term used in French, Spanish, and other Romance languages.
Steelworks
Only 1 STEELWORKS can be built in each empire. Requires city to have an Armory and an Industrial Zone that's built next to an Iron resource
naces replaced former methods. An integrated STEELWORKS in the 19th centuryby about two millennia.

After the invention of the Bessemer process, converters became widespread, and the appellation steelworks replaced ironworks. The processes carried at ironworks Steelers are usually described as ferrous metallurgy, but the term siderurgy is also occasionally used. This is derived from the Greek words sideros - iron and ergon or ergos - work. This is an unusual term in English, and it is best regarded as an anglicisation of a term used in French, Spanish, and other Romance languages.
Central Bank

Statue
Provides +1 loyalty per turn in this city. If the city is at full-loyalty, provides an additional 2 Faith [ICON_FAITH]. Earns +1 [ICON_CULTURE] for each era since constructed or repaired

As soon as humans began to settle down to build farms, granaries, shrines... Other humans came to “conquer” their peers, placing a statue of their leader, god, or both as a way to cement their budding empires foundation. As soon as kings created vast empires, they built statues like the Sphinxes in Egypt or the Terracotta Army in China. But perhaps the most famous statue, isn't even a statue at all, but a poem about Ramses II by Percy Bysshe Shelley— Ozymandias:

And on the pedestal, these words appear: / My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings; / Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair! / Nothing beside remains. Round the decay / Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare / The lone and level sands stretch far away.”
Courthouse
Provides +1 [ICON_HOUSING] Housing, +1 [ICON_AMENITIES], and +8 Loyalty per turn (Other effects) in this city. If the city is at full-loyalty, provides an additional +3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

Moreso than any other building in a town or city, the courthouse- also called court buildings, palace of justice, or courts- represents the symbolic link between the government and its citizens. The meaning of a judicial assembly is first attested in the 12th century, and derives from the earlier usage to designate a sovereign and his entourage, which met to adjudicate disputes in such an enclosed yard. The verb “to court”, meaning to win favor, derives from the same source since people traveled to the sovereign's court to win his favor.
Hospital
Provides +5 [ICON_FOOD] Food
Hospitals used to be for poor people who couldn't afford a doctor to come visit them at their home. Today, it represents the pinnacle of industrial medicine for people to be treated of ailments.

+Odd numbered [ICON_GOLD] Gold from every other odd {1_Num : plural 1?district; other?districts;}.
+{3_num} [ICON_SCIENCE] Science from the adjacent Preserve {1_Num : plural 1?district; other?districts;}.
+{3_num} [ICON_CULTURE] Culture frome adjacent City Center.
+{2_num} [ICON_CULTURE] Culture frome adjacent Neighborhood {1_Num : plural 1?district; other?districts;}.
+{4_num} [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from the adjacent Natural Wonder {1_Num : plural 1?tile; other?tiles;}.
+{3_num} [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from the adjacent Government Plaza {1_Num : plural 1?district; other?districts;}.
+{1_num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold from the adjacent {1_Num : plural 1?Plantation; other?Plantations;}.
+{1_num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold from the adjacent {1_Num : plural 1?Camp; other?Camps;}.
+{1_num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold from the adjacent {1_Num : plural 1?Pasture; other?Pastures;}.
